message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Agent-Based Modeling in Economics and Finance: Past, Present, and Future
Paper Abstract: Agent-based modeling (ABM) is a novel computational methodology for representing the behavior of individuals in order to study social phenomena. Its use is rapidly growing in many fields. We review ABM in economics and finance and highlight how it can be used to relax conventional assumptions in standard economic models. ABM has enriched our understanding of markets, industrial organization, labor, macro, development, public policy, and environmental economics. In financial markets, substantial accomplishments include understanding clustered volatility, market impact, systemic risk, and housing markets. We present a vision for how ABMs might be used in the future to build more realistic models of the economy and review some of hurdles that must be overcome to achieve this. (JEL C63, D00, E00, G00)
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Macroeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroeconomics"},{"title":"Centre for Macroeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_for_Macroeconomics"},{"title":"Journal of Macroeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Macroeconomics"},{"title":"Category:Macroeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Macroeconomics"},{"title":"AP Macroeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AP_Macroeconomics"},{"title":"New classical macroeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_classical_macroeconomics"},{"title":"History of macroeconomic thought - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_macroeconomic_thought"},{"title":"Investment (macroeconomics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_(macroeconomics)"},{"title":"Microeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microeconomics"},{"title":"Disequilibrium macroeconomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disequilibrium_macroeconomics"}]

## Macroeconomics

Macroeconomics is a branch of economics that deals with the performance, structure, behavior, and decision-making of an economy as a whole, including regional, national, and global economies.(no content)Macroeconomists study aggregate measures of the economy, such as output or gross domestic product (GDP), national income, unemployment, inflation, consumption, saving, investment, or trade.

### Key Characteristics

Macroeconomics and microeconomics are the two most general fields in economics, with macroeconomists focusing on large-scale phenomena or aggregate variables, differing significantly from microeconomists who study at a smaller level of analysis—either firms or consumers.(no content)The three central macroeconomic variables are output, unemployment, and inflation.(no content)Macroeconomics is further divided into topics depending on the time frame of analysis: short-term fluctuations over the business cycle, medium-term determinants of aggregate variables like unemployment, and long-term economic growth.

### Historical Development

Macroeconomics as a separate field of research and study is generally recognized to start in 1936, when John Maynard Keynes published his The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money.(no content)Since World War II, various macroeconomic schools of thought like Keynesians, monetarists, new classical and new Keynesian economists have made contributions to the development of mainstream research.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of labor economics:

## What is Labor Economics?

Labour economics is the subfield of economics concerned with the study of labour as an input to economic production, broadly surveying labor markets and the economic decisions of agents participating in such markets.

## Key Topics and Concepts

Labor economics covers various aspects including supply and demand of labor services, personnel economics, distribution of income, unions and collective bargaining, and labor markets and demographics.

## How Labor Markets Work

In microeconomic studies, workers make rational choices based on information regarding wage and desire for leisure to maximize utility, while economic firms seek to maximize profits by hiring laborers.(no content)Neoclassical economists view the labour market as similar to other markets in that the forces of supply and demand jointly determine the wage rate and quantity of people employed.

## Academic Research

The field is supported by several major academic institutions and publications. Labour Economics is a bimonthly peer-reviewed academic journal established in 1993 and is the official journal of the European Association of Labour Economists. Additionally, Research in Labor Economics is a biannual series that publishes peer-reviewed research applying economic theory and econometrics to analyze policy issues.

Here are the search results for "Environmental economics":

## Overview

Environmental economics "undertakes theoretical or empirical studies of the economic effects of national or local environmental policies around the world."(no content)It has become a widely studied subject due to growing environmental concerns in the twenty-first century.

## Key Concepts and Distinctions

Environmental economics fits within traditional economic theories and focuses on the efficient allocation of natural resources in order to fulfill human wants. This differs from ecological economics, which treats the economy as a subsystem of Earth's larger ecosystem, and emphasizes the preservation of natural capital.

## Historical Development

The term "environmental economics" became popular beginning in the 1960s. However, the entwinement of environmentalism and economics started much earlier, with economist Marquis de Condorcet in the 18th century, who had an interest in the link between economic activity and environmental issues.(no content)Central to environmental economics is the concept of market failure.

## Research Areas

Traditional areas of environmental and natural resource economics include welfare theory, land/location use, pollution control, resource extraction, and non-market valuation, and also resource exhaustibility, sustainability, environmental management, and environmental policy.

## Professional Organizations

The Association of Environmental and Resource Economists (AERE) was founded in 1979 in the United States as a means of exchanging ideas, stimulating research, and promoting graduate training in environmental and natural resource economics.

Links: [{"title":"Environmental economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_economics"},{"title":"Ecological economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_economics"},{"title":"Economics for Equity and the Environment Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics_for_Equity_and_the_Environment_Network"},{"title":"Category:Environmental economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Environmental_economics"},{"title":"Natural resource economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_resource_economics"},{"title":"Association of Environmental and Resource Economists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_Environmental_and_Resource_Economists"},{"title":"Category:Environmental economists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Environmental_economists"},{"title":"Bounded rationality in environmental decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_rationality_in_environmental_decision_making"},{"title":"Natural resource valuation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_resource_valuation"},{"title":"Environmental policy of the Biden administration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_Joe_Biden_administration"}]

Here are the search results for "Environmental economics":

## Overview

Environmental economics "undertakes theoretical or empirical studies of the economic effects of national or local environmental policies around the world."(no content)It has become a widely studied subject due to growing environmental concerns in the twenty-first century.

## Key Concepts and Distinctions

Environmental economics fits within traditional economic theories and focuses on the efficient allocation of natural resources in order to fulfill human wants. This differs from ecological economics, which treats the economy as a subsystem of Earth's larger ecosystem, and emphasizes the preservation of natural capital.

## Historical Development

The term "environmental economics" became popular beginning in the 1960s. However, the entwinement of environmentalism and economics started much earlier, with economist Marquis de Condorcet in the 18th century, who had an interest in the link between economic activity and environmental issues.(no content)Central to environmental economics is the concept of market failure.

## Research Areas

Traditional areas of environmental and natural resource economics include welfare theory, land/location use, pollution control, resource extraction, and non-market valuation, and also resource exhaustibility, sustainability, environmental management, and environmental policy.

## Professional Organizations

The Association of Environmental and Resource Economists (AERE) was founded in 1979 in the United States as a means of exchanging ideas, stimulating research, and promoting graduate training in environmental and natural resource economics.

Links: [{"title":"Housing market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Housing_market"},{"title":"Australian property market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_property_market"},{"title":"Canadian property bubble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_property_bubble"},{"title":"California housing shortage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_housing_shortage"},{"title":"2000s United States housing bubble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000s_United_States_housing_bubble"},{"title":"Subprime mortgage crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subprime_mortgage_crisis"},{"title":"Housing affordability in anglophone countries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_housing_markets_by_real_estate_prices"},{"title":"Real estate economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_estate_economics"},{"title":"2008 financial crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007–2008_financial_crisis"},{"title":"The Big Short (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Big_Short_(film)"}]

I've completed a web search for "Housing market." Here's what I found:

## Overview

The housing market refers to the economics of real estate used for residential purposes and the real estate business of buying, selling, or renting real estate.(no content)The housing market includes features such as the supply of housing, demand for housing, house prices, the rented sector, and government intervention.

## Key Characteristics

The housing market means the supply and demand for houses, usually in a particular country or region.(no content)The stock of real estate supply in any period is determined by the existing stock in the previous period, the rate of deterioration of the existing stock, the rate of renovation, and the flow of new development in the current period.

## Current Market Issues

Several regions are facing housing challenges:

- **California**: In 2025, the shortage was still estimated at 3 million housing units.
- **Australia**: The residential housing market has seen drastic changes in prices in recent decades, with property prices soaring in major cities like Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth, Brisbane, and Hobart.
- **Canada**: By 2010, Canada began experiencing a synchronized housing bubble across the six largest residential real estate markets.

The search results also covered historical housing crises, including the 2000s United States housing bubble, which was a sharp run up and subsequent collapse of house asset prices affecting over half of the U.S. states.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Systemic risk"

Links: [{"title":"Systemic risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systemic_risk"},{"title":"Systemic Risk Centre - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systemic_Risk_Centre"},{"title":"Systemic Risk Council - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systemic_Risk_Council"},{"title":"Systematic risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_risk"},{"title":"European Systemic Risk Board - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Systemic_Risk_Board"},{"title":"Category:Systemic risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systemic_risk"},{"title":"International Risk Governance Center - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Risk_Governance_Council"},{"title":"Specific risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specific_risk"},{"title":"Valuation risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valuation_risk"},{"title":"Treynor ratio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treynor_ratio"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about systemic risk:

## Definition

In finance, systemic risk is the risk of collapse of an entire financial system or entire market, as opposed to the risk associated with any one individual entity, group or component of a system, that can be contained therein without harming the entire system.

## Key Characteristics

As depositors sense the ripple effects of default, and liquidity concerns cascade through money markets, a panic can spread through a market, with a sudden flight to quality, creating many sellers but few buyers for illiquid assets.(no content)Some companies are viewed as too big and too interconnected to fail.

## Measurement and Assessment

According to the Property Casualty Insurers Association of America, there are two key assessments for measuring systemic risk, the "too big to fail" (TBTF) and the "too (inter)connected to fail" (TCTF or TICTF) tests.

## Distinction from Systematic Risk

Systemic risk should not be confused with market or price risk as the latter is specific to the item being bought or sold and the effects of market risk are isolated to the entities dealing in that specific item.

## Regulatory Oversight

Several institutions have been established to monitor and address systemic risk:

- The Systemic Risk Centre (SRC) is a research centre in London, hosted at the London School of Economics and dedicated to the study of systemic risk and the development of policies for addressing the effects of financial crises.

- The European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) is tasked with the macro-prudential oversight of the financial system within the European Union in order to contribute to the prevention or mitigation of systemic risks to financial stability in the EU.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of public policy:

## Definition

Public policy is an institutionalized proposal or a decided set of elements like laws, regulations, guidelines, and actions to solve or address relevant and problematic social issues, guided by a conception and often implemented by programs.(no content)These policies govern and include various aspects of life such as education, health care, employment, finance, economics, transportation, and all over elements of society.

## Creation and Implementation

Diebold - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_X._Diebold"},{"title":"Capstone Investment Advisors - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capstone_Investment_Advisors"},{"title":"Cboe Global Markets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cboe_Global_Markets"},{"title":"Currency overlay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Currency_overlay"},{"title":"Beta (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beta_(finance)"},{"title":"Effects of the Great Recession - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effects_of_the_Great_Recession"},{"title":"IG Group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IG_Group"}]

I've performed a web search for "Financial markets volatility." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Measurement

Volatility is a statistical measure of dispersion around the average of any random variable such as market parameters.(no content)Implied volatility is derived from the market price of a market-traded derivative (in particular, an option), while actual volatility refers to the current volatility of a financial instrument for a specified period based on historical prices.

## Patterns in Market Volatility

Many types of assets experience periods of high and low volatility—during some periods, prices go up and down quickly, while during other times they barely move at all.(no content)Periods when prices fall quickly (a crash) are often followed by prices going down even more, or going up by an unusual amount, and a time when prices rise quickly may often be followed by prices going up even more, or going down by an unusual amount.

## Volatility Tracking

Cboe's key index options include those on the VIX, which tracks market volatility, and on the S&P 500 Index (SPX).(no content)The CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) was introduced in January 1993 to measure 30-day implied volatility of S&P 100 options, and in 2003, the underlying benchmark for the VIX was changed to the S&P 500.

## Historical Context

Financial markets have experienced significant volatility during major crises. January 2008 was an especially volatile month in world stock markets, with a surge in implied volatility measurements of the US-based S&P 500 index.

Web search results for query: "Industrial organization economics"

Links: [{"title":"Industrial organization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_organization"},{"title":"Joe Bain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Bain"},{"title":"Luís Cabral (economist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luis_Cabral_(economist)"},{"title":"Yingyao Hu - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yingyao_Hu"},{"title":"Richard Friberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Friberg"},{"title":"Stephen Salant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Salant"},{"title":"Richard M. Burton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_M._Burton"},{"title":"Michael Whinston - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Whinston"},{"title":"Steven L. Heston - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steven_L._Heston"},{"title":"Industrial Economics Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Economics_Institute"}]

Here are the search results for "Industrial organization economics":

## Definition and Scope

Industrial organization is a field that extends the theory of the firm by analyzing the structure of firms and markets, as well as the boundaries between them.(no content)It introduces real-world features that depart from the perfectly competitive model, such as transaction costs and imperfect information.

## Key Approaches

The field uses multiple methodologies:

- A descriptive approach provides an overview of industrial organization, such as measures of competition and the size-concentration of firms in an industry.

- A second approach uses microeconomic models to explain internal firm organization and market strategy, which includes internal research and development along with issues of internal reorganization and renewal.

- A third aspect is oriented to public policy related to economic regulation, antitrust law, and, more generally, the economic governance of law in defining property rights, enforcing contracts, and providing organizational infrastructure.

## Historical Development and Key Figures

The development of industrial organization as a separate field owes much to Edward Chamberlin, Joan Robinson, Edward S. Mason, J. M. Clark, Joe S. Bain and Paolo Sylos Labini, among others.(no content)Joe Bain developed the influential structure–conduct–performance (SCP) paradigm, which examines the relationships among market structure, firm behavior, and economic performance.

## Impact and Tools

The extensive use of game theory in industrial economics has led to the export of this tool to other branches of microeconomics, such as behavioral economics and corporate finance.(no content)Industrial organization has also had significant practical impacts on antitrust law and competition policy.

Links: [{"title":"Development economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_economics"},{"title":"Economic development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_development"},{"title":"Human development (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_development_(economics)"},{"title":"Category:Development economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Development_economics"},{"title":"Michael Todaro - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Todaro"},{"title":"Review of Development Economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Review_of_Development_Economics"},{"title":"Journal of Development Economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Development_Economics"},{"title":"Category:Development economists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Development_economists"},{"title":"Talk:Development economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Development_economics"},{"title":"Developmentalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developmentalism"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of development economics:

## Definition and Scope

Development economics is a branch of economics that deals with economic aspects of the development process in low- and middle- income countries.(no content)Its focus is not only on methods of promoting economic development, economic growth and structural change but also on improving the potential for the mass of the population, for example, through health, education and workplace conditions, whether through public or private channels.

## Key Topics and Approaches

Common topics include growth theory, poverty and inequality, human capital, and institutions.(no content)Development economics involves the creation of theories and methods that aid in the determination of policies and practices and can be implemented at either the domestic or international level.(no content)Unlike in many other fields of economics, approaches in development economics may incorporate social and political factors to devise particular plans.

## Historical Development

Historically, economic development policies focused on industrialization and infrastructure; since the 1960s, it has increasingly focused on poverty reduction.(no content)From the 1940s to the 1960s the state played a large role in promoting industrialization in developing countries, following the idea of modernization theory. This period was followed by a brief period of basic needs development focusing on human capital development and redistribution in the 1970s. Neoliberalism emerged in the 1980s pushing an agenda of free trade and removal of import substitution industrialization policies.

Human development has also become an important aspect, with international organisations such as the United Nations and the World Bank adopting human development as a holistic approach to evaluating a country's progress that considers living conditions, social relations, individual freedoms and political institutions that contribute to freedom and well-being, in addition to standard measures of income growth.

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Agent-based_modeling&redirect=no"},{"title":"Swarm (simulation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(simulation)"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Repast (modeling toolkit) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Repast_(modeling_toolkit)"},{"title":"Joshua M. Epstein - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua_M._Epstein"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"}]

Here are the search results for **Agent-based modeling**:

## Overview

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

## Key Characteristics

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena through emergence, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts, and higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.(no content)Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

## Implementation

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

## Historical Development

The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s, but since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

## Applications

Agent-based modeling has diverse applications across multiple fields, including:
- Ecological contexts for modeling the behavior of different species such as insects infestations, invasive species, and aquatic populations
- Social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts
- Business and technology problems since the mid-1990s

Links: [{"title":"Volatility clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volatility_clustering"},{"title":"Financial models with long-tailed distributions and volatility clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_models_with_long-tailed_distributions_and_volatility_clustering"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference desk/Archives/Mathematics/2007 June 9 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Mathematics/2007_June_9"},{"title":"Stochastic volatility jump models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_volatility_jump_models"},{"title":"Category:Financial models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Financial_models"},{"title":"Stochastic volatility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_volatility"},{"title":"Volatility (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volatility_(finance)"},{"title":"Financial modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_modeling"},{"title":"Time series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_series"},{"title":"Lattice model (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_model_(finance)"}]

## Summary of Volatility Clustering

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about volatility clustering:

### Definition

Volatility clustering refers to the observation, first noted by Mandelbrot (1963), that "large changes tend to be followed by large changes, of either sign, and small changes tend to be followed by small changes."

### Key Characteristics

While returns themselves are uncorrelated, absolute returns or their squares display a positive, significant and slowly decaying autocorrelation function, with correlations ranging from a few minutes to several weeks.

### Limitations of Classical Models

Classical financial models typically assume homoskedasticity and normality and cannot explain stylized phenomena such as skewness, heavy tails, and volatility clustering of empirical asset returns.

### Modeling Approaches

The ARCH (Engle, 1982) and GARCH (Bollerslev, 1986) models aim to more accurately describe volatility clustering and related effects, with the main idea being that volatility is dependent upon past realizations of the asset process and related volatility process.(no content)This represents a more precise formulation of the intuition that asset volatility tends to revert to some mean rather than remaining constant or moving in monotonic fashion over time.

Additionally, modern approaches like stochastic volatility models and stochastic volatility jump (SVJ) models have been developed to capture volatility clustering alongside other empirical features of financial markets.

Links: [{"title":"Volatility clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volatility_clustering"},{"title":"Financial models with long-tailed distributions and volatility clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_models_with_long-tailed_distributions_and_volatility_clustering"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference desk/Archives/Mathematics/2007 June 9 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Mathematics/2007_June_9"},{"title":"Stochastic volatility jump models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_volatility_jump_models"},{"title":"Category:Financial models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Financial_models"},{"title":"Stochastic volatility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_volatility"},{"title":"Volatility (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volatility_(finance)"},{"title":"Financial modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_modeling"},{"title":"Time series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_series"},{"title":"Lattice model (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_model_(finance)"}]

## Summary of Volatility Clustering

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about volatility clustering:

### Definition

Volatility clustering refers to the observation, first noted by Mandelbrot (1963), that "large changes tend to be followed by large changes, of either sign, and small changes tend to be followed by small changes."

### Key Characteristics

While returns themselves are uncorrelated, absolute returns or their squares display a positive, significant and slowly decaying autocorrelation function, with correlations ranging from a few minutes to several weeks.

### Limitations of Classical Models

Classical financial models typically assume homoskedasticity and normality and cannot explain stylized phenomena such as skewness, heavy tails, and volatility clustering of empirical asset returns.

### Modeling Approaches

The ARCH (Engle, 1982) and GARCH (Bollerslev, 1986) models aim to more accurately describe volatility clustering and related effects, with the main idea being that volatility is dependent upon past realizations of the asset process and related volatility process.(no content)This represents a more precise formulation of the intuition that asset volatility tends to revert to some mean rather than remaining constant or moving in monotonic fashion over time.

Additionally, modern approaches like stochastic volatility models and stochastic volatility jump (SVJ) models have been developed to capture volatility clustering alongside other empirical features of financial markets.

Links: [{"title":"Market impact - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_impact"},{"title":"Financial market impact of the COVID-19 pandemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_market_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic"},{"title":"Impact investing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_investing"},{"title":"Market microstructure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_microstructure"},{"title":"Financial market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_market"},{"title":"Capital market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_market"},{"title":"Money market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Money_market"},{"title":"Profit Impact of Market Strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profit_Impact_of_Market_Strategy"},{"title":"Category:Financial markets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Financial_markets"},{"title":"Outline of finance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_finance_topics"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about market impact in finance:

## Definition

In financial markets, market impact is the effect that a market participant has when it buys or sells an asset. It is the extent to which the buying or selling moves the price against the buyer or seller, i.e., upward when buying and downward when selling.

## Relationship to Market Liquidity

Market impact is closely related to market liquidity; in many cases the terms are synonymous.

## Importance for Large Investors

Market impact is a key consideration before any decision to move money within or between financial markets, especially for large investors. If the amount of money being moved is large (relative to the turnover of the asset(s) in question), then the market impact can be several percentage points and needs to be assessed alongside other transaction costs.

## Management Strategies

The financial institution that is seeking to manage its market impact needs to limit the pace of its activity (e.g., keeping its activity below one-third of daily turnover) so as to avoid disrupting the price.

## Market Impact Cost

Market impact cost is a measure of market liquidity that reflects the cost faced by a trader of an index or security. The market impact cost is measured in the chosen numeraire of the market, and is how much additionally a trader must pay over the initial price due to market slippage, i.e. the cost incurred because the transaction itself changed the price of the asset.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title; relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes); entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other; wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/); relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Agent-Based Modeling in Economics and Finance: Past, Present, and Future". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey (literature review and overview of agent-based modeling research)

**Entities Identified:** 11 triples extracted from the paper's title and abstract:

1. **Agent-based model** (method) - Core methodology reviewed for economic/financial simulation
2. **Industrial organization** (task) - Field where ABM analyzes market structure
3. **Labour economics** (task) - Domain for ABM labor market studies
4. **Macroeconomics** (task) - Macro-level economic behavior modeling
5. **Development economics** (task) - Economic development process understanding
6. **Public policy** (task) - Evidence-based policy evaluation through ABM
7. **Environmental economics** (task) - Environmental impact and sustainability modeling
8. **Volatility clustering** (concept) - Financial market phenomenon explained by ABM
9. **Market impact** (concept) - Trading activity effects on prices
10. **Systemic risk** (concept) - Financial stability through interconnected agents
11. **Housing market** (task) - Real estate market dynamics and bubble analysis

**Validation Status:** All checks passed ✅
- Paper type correctly set to "survey"
- All 11 triples have complete required fields
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid
- Entity type distribution: 1 method, 7 tasks, 3 concepts

The triples_output.json file has been successfully updated with all entities, their relationships to the paper, appropriate entity types, verified Wikipedia URLs, and relevance descriptions.
